docs.lead_paragraph: If a movie were made about Dr. Donald L. Morton, its plot would go like this: A coal miner's son grows up in West Virginia in a house without electricity and running water. He becomes a top cancer surgeon and helps develop a technique that spares countless patients arduous operations. He also develops melanoma, the deadly skin cancer he specializes in treating. He survives. The starring role would be played by John Wayne, were he still alive. In real life, Dr. Morton cared for Mr. Wayne when he was dying of gastric cancer in 1979. In gratitude, the actor's children support the John Wayne Cancer Institute, the research center here that Dr. Morton runs. A big man with a square jaw, Dr. Morton, 68, even vaguely resembles Wayne.

headline.main: Cancer Pioneer Aims To Market a Vaccine

docs.abstract: Dr Donald L Morton has dedicated more than 40 years to cancer research in hopes of developing cancer vaccine; evidence that human immune system can, when activated, fight cancer within body has stimulated his research into vaccine for melanoma, which is currently in late-stage clinical trials with CancerVax company; his background as researcher and physician and his his contribution as developer of sentenel lymph node biopsies is discussed; he is currently director of John Wayne Cancer Institute, named after famous actor he treated for cancer in 1970's; photo (M)
